deliberation: The verse narrates elders coming and sitting before Ezekiel. Expressions are spatial and actional with no obvious metaphor, personification, or idiom beyond normal narrative description.

Considered whether this is purely formulaic or also figurative. The phrase ‘the word of YHWH came to me’ personifies the divine message as a moving entity and uses ‘word’ metonymically for revelation.

instances.english_text: And the word of GOD came to me:
target: YHWH’s act of revealing a message to Ezekiel
vehicle: a ‘word’ that travels and arrives like a person or object
movement and arrival of a messenger
ground: the message originates with God and reaches the prophet at a particular moment
transmission and reception of communication
relational-communicative
instances.explanation: ‘Word’ stands metonymically for God’s revelation, and it is personified as something that ‘comes’ to the prophet, a conventional anthropomorphic metaphor for divine speech.

deliberation: Looked for metaphors in the heart/face language. Found two vivid idiomatic metaphors: idols ‘on the heart’ and the ‘stumbling block of iniquity’ set before the face.

instances.english_text: these men have turned their thoughts upon their fetishes (lit. ‘have brought up their idols upon their heart’)
vehicle: location of objects on a bodily organ
ground: what dominates the ‘heart’ governs the person
domination/occupation by what one places at the center
control/priority
instances.explanation: Inner devotion is depicted metaphorically as physically placing idols on the heart, an idiom for fixing one’s mind and allegiance on them.

instances.english_text: and [they] set the stumbling block of their sin before their faces
target: their sinful idols and practices that lead to ruin
vehicle: a stumbling block placed directly in front of someone’s face
obstacle causing a fall in one’s path
ground: their chosen sin is the very thing that makes them fall and is kept constantly before them
self-caused harm through what one continually faces
cause-effect in moral choices
instances.explanation: Their sin, especially idolatry, is portrayed as a ‘stumbling block’ they themselves put in front of their own faces, a metaphor for self-imposed spiritual ruin.

deliberation: Verse repeats and generalizes the prior imagery: idols ‘on the heart’ and the ‘stumbling block’ before the face, now in conditional form. Both are again distinct metaphors/idioms.

instances.english_text: turns their thoughts upon their fetishes (lit. ‘brings up his idols upon his heart’)
target: an Israelite’s inward devotion and planning
ground: fixing something firmly in one’s inner core as central
internalization/centralization of what one values
priority of allegiance
instances.explanation: To ‘bring up idols upon the heart’ is an idiomatic metaphor for making idols the focus of one’s inner life and trust.

instances.english_text: and sets his mind upon the sin through which he stumbled (lit. ‘puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face’)
vehicle: an obstacle placed right before the face on one’s path
ground: one’s own sin is both ever-present and the cause of downfall
obstacle one continually confronts and trips over
self-sabotaging behavior
instances.explanation: Sin is metaphorically a ‘stumbling block’ placed before the person’s own face, highlighting their responsibility for their own downfall.

deliberation: Key phrase is ‘to seize the house of Israel in their heart’, plus estrangement language. Both are figurative: God ‘seizing’ hearts and Israel ‘being estranged’ from Him.

instances.english_text: Thus I will hold the House of Israel to account for their thoughts (lit. ‘that I may seize the house of Israel by their heart’)

vehicle: seizing or catching someone by the heart
physical capture of a person by a body part
ground: God’s judgment reaches the innermost seat of will and desire
total control/exposure of what is inside
accountability

instances.english_text: because they have all been estranged from Me through their fetishes

ground: idolatry removes them from God’s sphere and presence
distance as an image of relational rupture
alienation

deliberation: Looked for repentance imagery. The commands to ‘turn back from your fetishes’ and ‘turn your faces from your abominations’ use motion/orientation metaphors for repentance.

changing direction as an image of changing loyalty
conversion/return
posture: urgently calling for a decisive break with idolatry
instances.explanation: Repentance is described as physically ‘turning back from’ idols, mapping moral change onto a change in travel direction.

instances.english_text: and turn your minds (lit. ‘your faces’) away from all your abominations

attention and direction aligned with facial orientation
rejection/avoidance

deliberation: Saw three idiomatic metaphors: ‘separates himself from following Me’, idols on the heart, and the stumbling block of iniquity before the face. All depict spiritual stance via spatial images.

physical distance as image of relational disloyalty
alienation/defection
instances.explanation: Covenant loyalty is conceptualized as walking ‘after’ God; to ‘separate from after’ Him is a spatial metaphor for apostasy.

instances.english_text: and turns their thoughts upon their fetishes (lit. ‘brings up his idols upon his heart’)
vehicle: placing objects on an inner organ

internalizing an external object of devotion
control/attachment
instances.explanation: Again, devotion to idols is imaged as physically putting them ‘upon the heart’, an idiom for inward enthronement of idols.

instances.english_text: and sets their mind upon the sins through which they stumbled (lit. ‘puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face’)

self-inflicted harm
instances.explanation: The sinner is pictured as putting the very obstacle that ruins him directly before his face—an image of deliberate, self-destructive fixation on sin.

deliberation: Found three idiomatic/judicial metaphors: God setting His face against someone, making them a sign and a proverb, and cutting them off from among the people.

ground: face orientation embodies relational stance (for or against)
to set one’s face against is to oppose decisively
opposition/rejection
instances.explanation: God’s adverse judgment is depicted as turning His ‘face’ against the person, a bodily metaphor and metonymy for attitude and action.

instances.english_text: and make them a sign and a byword

instances.english_text: and I will cut them off from the midst of My people

instances.explanation: To ‘cut off’ someone ‘from the midst of my people’ is an idiomatic metaphor of amputation for total exclusion or destruction.

deliberation: The central figurative phrase is God ‘stretching out His hand’ upon the prophet, an anthropomorphic metaphor for active judgment.

instances.english_text: I will stretch out My hand against him

exercise of divine power in judgment

bodily gesture of attack or intervention

human striking as image of divine judgment
forceful intervention

instances.explanation: God’s judgment is anthropomorphically described as stretching out His ‘hand’ against the prophet, a standard metaphor for exercising power.

deliberation: The phrase ‘they shall bear their punishment/iniquity’ uses a burden metaphor for guilt. No other strong figures appear.

instances.english_text: Thus they shall bear their punishment (lit. ‘their iniquity’)

responsibility/burden

deliberation: Noted two figurative elements: Israel ‘straying from after’ God (journey metaphor) and ‘defiling themselves’ with transgressions (ritual impurity image applied morally).

instances.english_text: so that the House of Israel may never again stray from Me (lit. ‘wander from after Me’)

direction of walking maps onto loyalty or disloyalty
guidance/followership
posture: desiring an end to their wandering
instances.explanation: Their religious unfaithfulness is figured as wandering off from following behind God, a journey metaphor for apostasy.

instances.english_text: and [that they] not defile themselves anymore with all their transgressions
ground: sin makes them unfit for God’s presence like dirt or impurity makes one unfit for worship
pollution as image of moral defilement
unfitness/contamination
instances.explanation: Their transgressions are portrayed as causing ritual-like ‘defilement’, mapping moral wrongdoing onto cultic impurity.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as v.2: ‘the word of YHWH came to me’. Again a personifying, metonymic idiom for divine revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me:

vehicle: approach of a messenger or object
ground: God’s message originates with Him and reaches the prophet like an arriving envoy
arrival indicates initiation and reception
communication event
posture: marking the authority of what follows
instances.explanation: The ‘word’ stands metonymically for the revelation itself, and is personified as coming to the prophet, an idiomatic anthropomorphic metaphor.

deliberation: Saw three figures: God ‘stretching out His hand’ (anthropomorphic action), ‘breaking the staff of bread’ (bread as support of life), and the merism ‘man and beast’.

instances.english_text: and I stretched out My hand against it

vehicle: a person extending a hand over something to strike or seize
ground: extended hand symbolizes deliberate, forceful action
human striking as image of divine judgment
decisive intervention
instances.explanation: God’s judgment is anthropomorphically pictured as stretching out His ‘hand’ against the land.

instances.english_text: and [I] broke its staff of bread

breaking the staff equals removing support
dependence/vulnerability

instances.explanation: Bread is metaphorically called a ‘staff’, portraying the food supply as a support for life that God can ‘break’.

instances.english_text: and cut off from it human and animal

two extremes encompass the whole set
completeness

instances.explanation: The pair ‘human and animal’ is a merism: by naming both, the verse conveys the total removal of all life from the land.

deliberation: Most of the verse is literal hypothetical, but ‘they will save their soul/life’ uses נֶפֶשׁ as a synecdoche for the whole person/life.

instances.english_text: they would by their righteousness save only themselves (lit. ‘their soul’)

ground: the ‘soul’ stands for the whole living person
part/inner aspect used for the whole entity
representative identity
instances.explanation: נַפְשָׁם (‘their soul’) functions as a synecdoche/metonymy for their own lives as whole persons.

deliberation: Wild beasts depopulating the land and leaving it desolate is presented straightforwardly as a possible judgment scenario; imagery is vivid but not clearly figurative beyond literal description.
The judgment statement is literal, but ‘sons and daughters’ functions as a merism for all offspring/descendants they might save.

instances.english_text: they would save neither sons nor daughters

two poles encompass the total set
completeness

instances.explanation: ‘Sons and daughters’ is a merism: by mentioning both, the text asserts that none of their offspring of any kind would be saved.

deliberation: Identified two figures: ‘bringing a sword upon the land’ (sword as metonymy for war) and again the merism ‘man and beast’.

deliberation: Detected two figures: ‘pouring out My fury upon it in blood’ (wrath as liquid) and again the merism ‘man and beast’.

deliberation: Two figures parallel earlier verses: ‘sons and daughters’ as a merism for all offspring and ‘save their soul’ as synecdoche/metonymy for saving their own lives.
